title: 108_hr2188
content:
The "Safety Net Extension Act" amends the Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 to extend the program until November 30. It also provides additional weeks of benefits. The Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 is amended to provide additional weeks of benefits equal to 8 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount. The amendment takes effect immediately and applies to weeks of unemployment starting from the enactment date. The Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 is amended to provide additional weeks of benefits based on exhaustion of amounts occurring after the enactment date. TITLE II--FEDERAL UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFIT SYSTEM REFORMS

SEC. 201. EXTENDED BENEFITS TRIGGER amended to lower percentage trigger for extended benefits.

SEC. 202. INCREASE AND DECREASE IN EARNINGS CREDITED TO STATE ACCOUNTS based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. "Increase and Decrease in Earnings Allocated to State Accounts based on Meeting or Failing to Meet Funding Goals" If the average daily balance in a State account in the Unemployment Trust Fund exceeds the funding goal, the amount credited will increase by the interest premium. If the balance is below the funding goal, the amount credited will decrease by the interest penalty, with a limit of $2,500,000. The formula for calculating the interest premium or penalty in a State's Unemployment Trust Fund account is based on the excess of the average daily balance over the funding goal. The amount credited is determined by specific percentages for each State, with a cap of $2,500,000. The Secretary adjusts interest premiums if they exceed penalties. An interest penalty is half a percent of the excess funding goal for the State with the largest percentage, and a product of the amount credited and a percentage for other States. The funding goal for a State is calculated based on the average unemployment benefits paid over a 20-year period. The term "percentage value" is defined in relation to any excess of the average daily balance. The funding goal for a State is calculated based on the average unemployment benefits paid over a 20-year period. The term "percentage value" is defined in relation to any excess of the average daily balance in a State account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Amendments are made to section 904 of the Social Security Act regarding amounts credited to state accounts and the interest rate on repayment of advances. Amendments to section 1202(b)(4) of the Social Security Act involve crediting interest premiums under subsection (h) of section 904. The Secretary of Labor must report funding sources for interest premiums if penalties are insufficient. These amendments apply to calendar years after December 31, 2006. SEC. 203 amends the Social Security Act to restrict interest-free advances to states meeting funding goals in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The amendment applies to calendar years after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, TITLE III suspends taxes on unemployment compensation for 2 years under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SECTION 301 suspends taxes on unemployment compensation for 2 years starting in 2003 or 2004. SECTION 302 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow states to collect federal unemployment tax. At the election of a certified State, employers paying contributions into an unemployment fund must submit the tax to the State instead of the Secretary. Payment to the State is considered timely if made alongside contributions to the fund. Employers must submit the tax to the State instead of the Secretary, and it must be paid on time to be considered timely. The State must then transmit the tax amount to the Secretary along with employer tax returns. Regulations may require additional information from the State regarding the tax payable by each employer. The Code is amended by replacing the item for section 3311 with new items. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. Required distribution of state-specific information packets is mandated. SEC. 303 amends the Internal Revenue Code to require states to distribute State-specific information packets to explain unemployment insurance eligibility conditions. This amendment applies to certifications of States for 2003, with a deadline of July 1, 2004, for compliance if the state legislature does not meet in a regular session closing in 2003. TITLE IV--TRADE ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE PROVISIONS

SEC. 401. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

    Amends Trade Act of 1974 to extend Adjustment Assistance for Workers, Firms, and Farmers until September 30, 2009.

SEC. 402. DELEGATION OF FUNCTIONS TO CARRY OUT ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE FOR FIRMS PROGRAM. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to delegate functions to the International Trade Administration, with an effective date 60 days after enactment.
